headline.main: MISSION HAILED IN INDIA AS STEP INTO SPACE

results.snippet: A joint mission with the Soviet Union that is to put India's first man in space on Tuesday is being hailed here both as a modest step forward in this country's plans to explore space and as an example of the cooperative relationship that has...
results.lead_paragraph: A joint mission with the Soviet Union that is to put India's first man in space on Tuesday is being hailed here both as a modest step forward in this country's plans to explore space and as an example of the cooperative relationship that has developed between India and the Soviet Union. The Indian astronaut, Rakesh Sharma, a 35-year-old squadron leader in the Indian Air Force, is to join two Russian astronauts in the eight-day scientific mission. India is not likely to have its own manned space program for a long time, if ever, and Mr. Sharma's flight may well be the last by an Indian for a lorng time. Nevertheless, he is not merely going along for the rise, and he will be doing more than simply asserting national pride and identity when he practices his yoga.

headline.main: No Headline

results.snippet: PAMELA REED, who won acclaim Off Broadway five years ago as the raging girl in Marsha Norman's ''Getting Out,'' and who plays the rebellious, frightened wife of the astronaut Gordon Cooper in the film ''The Right Stuff,'' is busy with four other...
results.lead_paragraph: PAMELA REED, who won acclaim Off Broadway five years ago as the raging girl in Marsha Norman's ''Getting Out,'' and who plays the rebellious, frightened wife of the astronaut Gordon Cooper in the film ''The Right Stuff,'' is busy with four other roles right now. PAMELA REED TACKLES 4 ROLES IN 'FEN' They are all in Caryl Churchill's ''Fen,'' which reopened recently at the Public Theater with American actors playing multiple roles, as did their British counterparts last year. Miss Reed, whose performance received critical praise, is a sadistic stepmother, a 9-year-old girl, a Baptist leader and a little boy scaring crows. With all the quick changes to be made, she says, ''Backstage is as good a show as up front.'' Three dressers help with costumes and brush the actors off after each exit, because they get covered with the peat moss that blankets the stage to suggest potato fields. ''It gets in your nose,'' she said. ''We all have black toenails.''

headline.main: INDIAN JOINS SOVIET PAIR IN 8-DAY SPACE MISSION

results.snippet: The Soviet Union today launched an Indian astronaut into space for the first time, along with two Soviet astronauts.    Rakesh Sharma, a 35-year-old Indian Air Force pilot, joined the two Soviet astronauts for an eight-day visit to the Salyut 7...
results.lead_paragraph: The Soviet Union today launched an Indian astronaut into space for the first time, along with two Soviet astronauts. Rakesh Sharma, a 35-year-old Indian Air Force pilot, joined the two Soviet astronauts for an eight-day visit to the Salyut 7 space station, where three other Soviet astronauts have been living since Feb. 8. The joint flight, the 11th in the ''intercosmos'' series that has taken non- Soviet astronauts into space along with Soviet astronauts, is to include medical experiments in which Mr. Sharma will practice yoga as a possible means of coping with space sickness. The experiments also include detailed space surveys of the Indian subcontinent. But Western experts expect that, like the 10 previous joint flights, this one will probably be less notable for scientific achievement than for claims of new levels of Soviet-Indian relations.

headline.main: SHUTTLE TEAM PREPARED TO REPAIR U.S. SATELLITE

results.snippet: The countdown began today for the launching Friday of the space shuttle Challenger on a planned six-day mission to track down and attempt to repair an ailing scientific satellite.   All preparations for the first such repair mission to an orbiting...
results.lead_paragraph: The countdown began today for the launching Friday of the space shuttle Challenger on a planned six-day mission to track down and attempt to repair an ailing scientific satellite. All preparations for the first such repair mission to an orbiting satellite were reported proceeding smoothly toward a scheduled liftoff at 8:59 A.M. It will be the 11th flight of the space shuttles, and the Challenger's fifth. Thunderstorms and heavy rains lashed the launching base as technicians began work early this morning. But because they were mostly working indoors, checking flight systems by remote control, the storm caused no problems. The weather for launching morning is expected to be excellent.

headline.main: SKETCHES OF THE 5 MEN ABOARD THE CHALLENGER

results.snippet: James D. Van Hoften    Dr. Van Hoften, nicknamed ''Ox,'' stands 6 feet 4 inches tall and weighs 200 pounds . . . chief task on this mission is to don a space suit, enter the cargo bay and replace a defective guidance module in the ailing Solar Max...
results.lead_paragraph: James D. Van Hoften Dr. Van Hoften, nicknamed ''Ox,'' stands 6 feet 4 inches tall and weighs 200 pounds . . . chief task on this mission is to don a space suit, enter the cargo bay and replace a defective guidance module in the ailing Solar Max satellite . . . Born in Fresno, Calif., on June 11, 1944, he attended the University of California at Berkeley before joining the Navy aviation program in 1969 . . . flew about 60 combat missions over Southeast Asia while assigned to the carrier Ranger . . . In 1974 returned to academic studies and obtained a doctorate from Colorado State University on his research into inteactions between waves and turbulent channel flow. . . . As an assistant professor at the University of Houston he taught fluid mechanics . . . selected as an astronaut candidate in 1978 and, after one year of training, was certified as a mission specialist . . . From 1979 until the first shuttle flight in April 1981 took part in the testing of shuttle guidance, navigation and flight control systems . . . His hobbies include skiing, jogging, handball and racquetball . . . is married and has three children. Robert L. Crippen Captain Crippen of the Navy is on his third shuttle mission . . . was born in Beaumont, Tex., on Sept. 11, 1937 and graduated in 1960 from the University of Texas with a degree in aerospace engineering . . . acted as pilot on the first space shuttle mission in April 1981 and commanded the seventh flight last June . . . After graduation from the university entered the Navy's aviation officer program and from 1962 to 1964 served as an attack pilot aboard the carrier Independence . . . then entered the Air Force's aerospace research pilot school for test pilot training at Edwards Air Force Base in California . . . remained there after graduation as an instructor until he was selected in 1966 for the Air Force's manned orbiting laboratory program . . . was appointed an astronaut in 1969 and took part in a 56-day simulation of medical tests and other procedures to be conducted in orbit on the Skylab mission . . . was in the astronaut support crew for the second, third and fourth Skylab missions . . . performed a similar role for the 1976 Apollo-Soyuz test project in which Soviet and American spacecraft docked with one another in orbit.

headline.main: SPACE SHUTTLE OFF ON SATELLITE-REPAIR MISSION

results.snippet: Like handymen responding to a service call, five astronauts rode off in the space shuttle Challenger today, climbing at full throttle into high orbit, with bold plans to find, pick up and then repair a disabled scientific satellite.   The planned...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Like handymen responding to a service call, five astronauts rode off in the space shuttle Challenger today, climbing at full throttle into high orbit, with bold plans to find, pick up and then repair a disabled scientific satellite. The planned six-day mission, the first attempt to use the shuttle for servicing satellites, was launched on schedule at 8:58 A.M. After checking out the spaceship and finding that all aboard was well, the astronauts were set to handle their first task, the deployment of a 30-foot-long, 11-ton satellite carrying 57 experiments into the effects of the space environment on metals, electronics, other materials and tomato seeds. The satellite, the Long Duration Exposure Facility, is to be released into orbit Saturday morning. Then Capt. Robert L. Crippen of the Navy and Francis R. Scobee are to maneuver the Challenger higher and closer to their primary target, the Solar Max satellite that has been crippled for more than three years. They are to rendezvous with the satellite Sunday.

headline.main: THE OSCAR CHASE: A PEEK BEHIND THE SCREEN

results.snippet: LOS ANGELES     Can you buy an Oscar?  Probably not, but each spring Hollywood movie studios spend a great deal of money trying.  Ashley Boone, president of marketing at Columbia Pictures, estimates that approximately $400,000 apiece will have been...
results.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES Can you buy an Oscar? Probably not, but each spring Hollywood movie studios spend a great deal of money trying. Ashley Boone, president of marketing at Columbia Pictures, estimates that approximately $400,000 apiece will have been spent on each of the movies nominated for best picture - ''The Big Chill,'' ''The Dresser,'' ''The Right Stuff,'' ''Tender Mercies,'' and ''Terms of Endearment'' - by the time the envelopes are torn open tomorrow night. Irving Ivers, vice-president of advertising at M-G-M/ UA, thinks that Academy Award campaigns for some movies may cost half a million dollars. What the studios get for their money is not simply the prestige of winning Academy Awards. An award as best picture of the year can mean as much as $30 million at the box office. The night after its victory as the best movie of 1981, ''Chariots of Fire'' sold 100 per cent more tickets than it had sold a week earlier. In the next three weeks, the inspirational movie about two British runners in the 1924 Olympic Games earned nearly $15 million. And approximately half of ''The Deer Hunter's'' $60 million in ticket sales came after it was anointed as the best movie of 1978.

headline.main: SPACE CREW TO ATTEMPT HISTORIC REPAIR MISSION

results.snippet: When dawn comes in high orbit Sunday, the space shuttle Challenger should be flying in formation with Solar Max, a squat, 5,000-pound satellite.  It could be the dawn, too, of a new era of the human enterprise in space.   Shortly after 10 A.M.,...
results.lead_paragraph: When dawn comes in high orbit Sunday, the space shuttle Challenger should be flying in formation with Solar Max, a squat, 5,000-pound satellite. It could be the dawn, too, of a new era of the human enterprise in space. Shortly after 10 A.M., with the rising sun to his back and the Challenger beginning the 33d orbit of its mission, an astronaut wearing a jet-propulsion backpack is scheduled to fly the 200 feet from the spaceship to Solar Max. The backpack was successfully checked in untethered flights by astronauts on the previous shuttle mission in February.

headline.main: COMING TO TERMS WITH SUCCESS

results.snippet: WITH 'TERMS OF ENDEARMENT,' JAMES BROOKS HAS FOUND A NICHE AMONG HOLLYWOOD'S ELITE.    TOMORROW NIGHT, when the 56th annual Academy Awards are handed out, a man whose name is unknown to almost everybody in the television audience will be a...
results.lead_paragraph: WITH 'TERMS OF ENDEARMENT,' JAMES BROOKS HAS FOUND A NICHE AMONG HOLLYWOOD'S ELITE. TOMORROW NIGHT, when the 56th annual Academy Awards are handed out, a man whose name is unknown to almost everybody in the television audience will be a prominent contender for three of the golden statues. In fact, Hollywood considers James L. Brooks, this season's hot new writer-director, a heavy favorite. Even if Brooks loses, he won't be, ever again, just an anonymous television producer. Rags to riches, anonymity to fame--turning beggers into millionaires and soda jerks into Super Bowl quarterbacks--is a staple of countless movie plots. Given the way things work in Hollywood, turning a successful writer-producer of television situation comedies into the writer, producer and director of a movie that has been nominated for 11 Oscars was infinitely more difficult.

headline.main: CHALLENGER FAILS TO SEIZE SATELLITE FOR REPAIR EFFORT

results.snippet: The Challenger astronauts, try as they might with balky tools, a mechanical arm and even their gloved hands, failed in their ambitious attempt this morning to capture and repair the disabled Solar Max satellite more than 300 miles above the earth....

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The Challenger astronauts, try as they might with balky tools, a mechanical arm and even their gloved hands, failed in their ambitious attempt this morning to capture and repair the disabled Solar Max satellite more than 300 miles above the earth. But they planned to give it another try Monday or Tuesday morning in a determined effort to salvage the satellite - and the space shuttle's mission. Dr. George D. Nelson, hovering in space 200 feet from the shuttle, tried again and again to lock on to the crippled satellite and slow its spin. But as darkness approached and his fuel reserves dwindled, he was forced to abandon the bold mission and return to the ship. Satellite Becoming Stable Frank Cepollina, the manager of the Solar Max repair mission at the Goddard Space Center, said at a news conference late tonight that the satellite, which was left twisting and tumbling as a result of the retrieval effort, was responding to commands and was gradually settling down to a smoother flight.

headline.main: SENIOR YEAR IN GREAT NECK: A JUBILANT RITE OF PASSAGE

results.snippet: The road from ninth grade to senior year would be much more pleasant if it did not pass through life's first Bermuda Triangle, adolescence.   The one thing ninth graders at Great Neck South High School have in common is that they are little. As a...
results.lead_paragraph: The road from ninth grade to senior year would be much more pleasant if it did not pass through life's first Bermuda Triangle, adolescence. The one thing ninth graders at Great Neck South High School have in common is that they are little. As a ninth grader, Scott Currie felt too small to offer opinions. If he had a wild urge, he would go to the school library, put on his headphones and quietly listen to punk rock. His hero was an upperclassman named Lyle who slept in school by day and by night played drums for a punk band in Greenwich Village. Tenth grade is no picnic either. Eric Gordon was completely isolated his sophomore year. ''I felt inadequate socially, I just didn't fit in,'' he said. ''I had a bleak outlook.'' He took contentious stands - announcing, for instance, that poetry was stupid. When his class studied ''The Catcher in the Rye,'' he was shocked to find he was exactly like Holden Caulfield. It happens to 10th graders all the time, his English teacher, Marcia Weinberg, says. Without fail, several 10th graders will tell her privately that they are cracking up, just like Holden. This year, after lecturing on Dostoyevsky and Camus, Mrs. Weinberg also discovered she had a Raskolnikov and a Stranger in class.

headline.main: DUVALL AND MISS MACLAINE HONORED

results.snippet: As most of the movie industry had expected, ''Terms of Endearment'' - a tragicomedy about the relationship of a mother and daughter over a period of 30 years - took the lion's share of the major Academy Awards tonight. Paramount's ''Terms of...
results.lead_paragraph: As most of the movie industry had expected, ''Terms of Endearment'' - a tragicomedy about the relationship of a mother and daughter over a period of 30 years - took the lion's share of the major Academy Awards tonight. Paramount's ''Terms of Endearment'' collected five awards - best picture, director, screenplay, Shirley MacLaine as best actress and Jack Nicholson as best supporting actor - in the 56th annual ceremonies at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion of the Los Angeles Music Center. James L. Brooks - the producer, director and screenwriter of ''Terms of Endearment'' - went home with three of the golden Oscars. On his first trip to the stage, to receive an award for best screenplay adapted from another source, Mr. Brooks, who is best known as the creator of such television situation comedies as ''Taxi'' and ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show,'' thanked the author of ''Terms of Endearment,'' Larry McMurtry, for ''a wonderful book.'' When he came back a second time, for his award as best director, he seemed almost in tears and could only say, ''I'm overwhelmed.'' It took Mr. Brooks, who had never directed a movie before, four years to get a studio to make ''Terms of Endearment.'' Duvall Wins Best Actor Holding his Oscar for best picture, he said that even though Hollywood studios had turned ''Terms of Endearment'' down, it was ''more significant that a Hollywood studio made the movie.''

headline.main: ASTRONAUT TELLS OF GAINS IN CURING SPACE SICKNESS

results.snippet: Scientists are on the verge of conquering space sickness after experiments showed how that illness differed from Earth-bound motion sickness, says an astronaut who studied the malady on a recent shuttle mission.   Experiments conducted on the space...
results.lead_paragraph: Scientists are on the verge of conquering space sickness after experiments showed how that illness differed from Earth-bound motion sickness, says an astronaut who studied the malady on a recent shuttle mission. Experiments conducted on the space shuttle in September revealed some surprising effects of weightlessness on body functions, said the astronaut, Dr. William Thornton, who at 55 years of age is America's oldest space veteran. ''The gut shuts down, it just stops functioning,'' he told 175 people at a University of North Carolina Medical School alumni luncheon on Saturday. ''That's why they were experiencing vomiting without nausea. The stomach would fill with gastric juices, but they weren't going anywhere. There would be a cold sweat, sudden vomiting and they would get flushed.''

headline.main: SHUTTLE SET FOR NEW EFFORT TO CAPTURE AILING SATELLITE

results.snippet: The Challenger astronauts, given a ''fighting chance'' to turn failure into triumph, plan to try again Tuesday to grab the crippled Solar Max satellite and haul it aboard the space shuttle for the first repair job in high orbit.   Encouraged by the...
results.lead_paragraph: The Challenger astronauts, given a ''fighting chance'' to turn failure into triumph, plan to try again Tuesday to grab the crippled Solar Max satellite and haul it aboard the space shuttle for the first repair job in high orbit. Encouraged by the success of ground controllers in stabilizing the twisting, tossing satellite, bringing it to a slow roll, the astronauts are set to maneuver the Challenger to within 30 feet of Solar Max and attempt to retrieve it with a grappling device at the end of the shuttle's mechanical arm. This operation was scheduled to begin shortly after 8 A.M. Eastern standard time. The 5,000-pound Solar Max eluded capture Sunday when a grasping tool carried by a spacewalking astronaut malfunctioned. His bumping efforts sent Solar Max into such an erratic tumble that it reduced to a slim hope any prospect of a successful retrieval. Four subsequent attempts to snare the satellite with the shuttle's 50-foot mechanical arm proved fruitless.

headline.main: 2 REPAIRMEN FROM SPACE SHUTTLE SET FOR 'SURGERY IN BOXING GLOVES'

results.snippet: The two spacesuit-clad astronauts assigned to repair the Solar Max satellite Wednesday morning compare the job to performing ''surgery in boxing gloves'' and say the pinching of their fingertips is ''bloody painful.''   The repairs are expected to...
results.lead_paragraph: The two spacesuit-clad astronauts assigned to repair the Solar Max satellite Wednesday morning compare the job to performing ''surgery in boxing gloves'' and say the pinching of their fingertips is ''bloody painful.'' The repairs are expected to require six hours, starting about 4:30 A.M., with the astronauts taking turns doing the delicate work. Dr. George D. Nelson and Dr. James D. van Hoften say practice has shown them the delicate work required for the repairs constantly forces the gloves of their pressurized spacesuit against their fingertips. After the job is done their fingernails will be ''black and blue.''

headline.main: No Headline

results.snippet: Official Says Chinese Will Join Shuttle Crew      WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) - A Chinese astronaut is expected to fly on a United States space shuttle mission and conduct joint experiments as early as 1990, a senior Administration official said...
results.lead_paragraph: Official Says Chinese Will Join Shuttle Crew WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) - A Chinese astronaut is expected to fly on a United States space shuttle mission and conduct joint experiments as early as 1990, a senior Administration official said today. The official, who asked not to be identified, said the mission would probably be announced on President Reagan's visit to China April 26 to May 2.

headline.main: SHUTTLE'S ROBOTIC ARM SNARES ERRANT SATELLITE

results.snippet: The Challenger astronauts reached out with their long robotic arm today to catch a failing satellite, Solar Max, and take it aboard the 305-mile-high space shuttle for the first major repair job in orbit.   ''O.K., we've got it,'' radioed Capt....

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The Challenger astronauts reached out with their long robotic arm today to catch a failing satellite, Solar Max, and take it aboard the 305-mile-high space shuttle for the first major repair job in orbit. ''O.K., we've got it,'' radioed Capt. Robert L. Crippen of the Navy, the Challenger's command pilot. Cheers and applause broke the expectant hush of Mission Control here. The mission had been plucked from the brink of failure after earlier frustrations. Terry J. Hart, the astronaut operating the 50-foot-long mechanical arm, grabbed the slowly rolling and wobbling satellite on the first try, locking on to a protruding knob the size of a fist. Then he hauled the 5,000-pound satellite into the shuttle's cargo bay, easing it into a cradle back near the tail section.

headline.main: RETRIEVAL OF SATELLITE: RISKS AND LUCK

results.snippet: After a free-flying astronaut failed to capture the ailing Solar Max satellite and the space shuttle's robot arm dramatically succeeded, space officials have been pointedly asked why they picked man over machine in the first place. Was it mere...
results.lead_paragraph: After a free-flying astronaut failed to capture the ailing Solar Max satellite and the space shuttle's robot arm dramatically succeeded, space officials have been pointedly asked why they picked man over machine in the first place. Was it mere grandstanding? Officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration say it was anything but that. They cite a surprising chain of events involving unexpected risk, sheer luck and, in the end, calm determination and self-assurance.

headline.main: BALKY BLACK BOX KEY TO OPERATION

results.snippet: The balky, 550-pound black box that the Challenger astronauts replaced on the satellite Solar Max today does a crucial job. It adjusts the position of the $235 million observatory so it can point its telescopes and scientific instruments with...
results.lead_paragraph: The balky, 550-pound black box that the Challenger astronauts replaced on the satellite Solar Max today does a crucial job. It adjusts the position of the $235 million observatory so it can point its telescopes and scientific instruments with incredible precision as it speeds through space at more than 17,000 miles an hour. The black box, called the attitude control module, is one of the most advanced control systems ever built. It failed in 1980 when three fuses, each less than half an inch long, blew.

headline.main: WRENCH WITH GOLDEN TOUCH

results.snippet: The historic fix-it job in space today would have been impossible without a device that Dr. James D. van Hoften calls his ''million-dollar wrench.''   The battery-powered device allowed Dr. van Hoften to remove an inoperative device, the 550-pound...
results.lead_paragraph: The historic fix-it job in space today would have been impossible without a device that Dr. James D. van Hoften calls his ''million-dollar wrench.'' The battery-powered device allowed Dr. van Hoften to remove an inoperative device, the 550-pound attitude control module, and install a new one.

headline.main: TWO ON SHUTTLE REPAIR DEFECTS OF AILING CRAFT

results.snippet: Two high- flying handymen of the space shuttle Challenger succeeded today in replacing defective electronics units on the crippled Solar Max satellite for the first extensive repair job in orbit.   They made it look easy, which was encouraging to...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Two high- flying handymen of the space shuttle Challenger succeeded today in replacing defective electronics units on the crippled Solar Max satellite for the first extensive repair job in orbit. They made it look easy, which was encouraging to planners of future space missions requiring the shuttles to make service calls on satellites for refueling, maintenance and even construction tasks. Working outside in the Challenger's cargo bay, where the 5,000-pound Solar Max was berthed, Dr. George D. Nelson and Dr. James D. van Hoften used power tools designed for weightless conditions to replace two large modules and fix a scientific instrument 305 miles above the earth. Plan to Release Satellite This restored the satellite to operational health for the first time in three years and perhaps added years to its useful lifetime. After hours of checking out Solar Max's condition, engineers at the Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md., said the overhauled satellite should be ready for redeployment in its own orbit Thursday morning. It was set to be released by the same mechanical arm that snared it and brought it aboard Tuesday.

headline.main: STUD ON SATELLITE MAY HAVE FOILED ASTRONAUT CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., April 11 (UPI) - The astronaut James van Hoften told ground controllers today that a small stud sticking out from the Solar Max satellite might have prevented a spacewalker from docking with it.

results.snippet: In a free flight in space from the space shuttle Sunday, another astronaut, George Nelson, tried to grab the satellite with a bulky assembly, the trunnion pin attachment device. But the device did not lock onto a docking pin on the side of the...
results.lead_paragraph: In a free flight in space from the space shuttle Sunday, another astronaut, George Nelson, tried to grab the satellite with a bulky assembly, the trunnion pin attachment device. But the device did not lock onto a docking pin on the side of the satellite. Terry Hart, another astronaut, snagged the satellite Tuesday using the shuttle's robot arm.

headline.main: GRAND-SCALE MALCOLM MORLEY

results.snippet: THERE can be little doubt now about Malcolm Morley's importance. As much as any painter of his generation, he has been following the path of the most resistance. During the last few years, his canvases have been rings in which he, Abstract...
results.lead_paragraph: THERE can be little doubt now about Malcolm Morley's importance. As much as any painter of his generation, he has been following the path of the most resistance. During the last few years, his canvases have been rings in which he, Abstract Expressionism, Pop Art, Conceptual Art and assorted modernist heavyweights have been hammering away at one another. Morley has helped preserve the urgency of one of the Abstract Expressionist questions: How is it possible for an artist to enlist in the just wars of 20th-century art and still produce painting of conviction and ambition? One of the problems with Morley's past work was that the conflicting forces in it could hammer away at one another to the point where paintings seemed slightly punchdrunk. A work that might at first seem wild, effusive and instinctive could wind up too stunned by the blow of Conceptual Art to be able to find its own corner. A painting that seemed an expression of Morley's robust sensuality could wind up almost bleak in its self-denial and abnegation. While Morley's method became increasingly influential, some work that resulted from that method seemed not so much generative as self-destructive and perverse.

headline.main: CAPE'S FICKLE WEATHER DIVERTS SHUTTLE AGAIN

results.snippet: With today's aborting of a landing at the Kennedy Space Center, bad weather has now forced the cancellation of two out of three planned shuttle landings here.    The fickle weather is a continuing worry for officials of the National Aeronautics...
results.lead_paragraph: With today's aborting of a landing at the Kennedy Space Center, bad weather has now forced the cancellation of two out of three planned shuttle landings here. The fickle weather is a continuing worry for officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration because of its costs in terms of time, money and convenience. If the weather problem can be solved, officials expect space shuttles eventually to take off and land at a rate of nearly once every two weeks.

headline.main: NUTS AND BOLTS OF INTERSTELLAR REPAIR

results.snippet: Space agency officials hailed the repair last week of the Solar Max satellite as the advent of a new age in space technology, now that humans can toil in the void with the tools of the mechanic's trade.    With Solar Max, the orbiting solar...
results.lead_paragraph: Space agency officials hailed the repair last week of the Solar Max satellite as the advent of a new age in space technology, now that humans can toil in the void with the tools of the mechanic's trade. With Solar Max, the orbiting solar observatory, at first the toil spelled only trouble. Over the weekend, a free-flying astronaut failed to capture the malfunctioning satellite, making matters worse when he sent it into an end-over-end tumble. Ground controllers were able to stabilize the craft, however, after which the astronauts stretched out the shuttle's mechanical arm and brought Solar Max into the cargo bay for the first major in-orbit repair job.

headline.main: SPACE SHUTTLE CONDITION CALLED 'REMARKABLE'

results.snippet: The $1 billion winged spaceship that returned Friday from a historic mission in space was pronounced in ''remarkable'' condition today after the rigors of a seven-day voyage outside the earth's atmosphere.    The flight of the Challenger, the 11th...
results.lead_paragraph: The $1 billion winged spaceship that returned Friday from a historic mission in space was pronounced in ''remarkable'' condition today after the rigors of a seven-day voyage outside the earth's atmosphere. The flight of the Challenger, the 11th in three years for the nation's growing fleet of space shuttles, was the first in which high-flying astronauts repaired a failed satellite in orbit. Their success paves the way for routine repairs and service calls in space.

headline.main: IN PLAIN ENGLISH, QUEBECERS DEFY FRENCH PURISTS

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: FRENCH LANGUAGE, COMMISSION FOR THE PROTECTION OF THE

results.snippet: The Commission for the Protection of the French Language, a Quebec provincial agency, is sometimes referred to as the vocabulary constabulary, or the tongue troopers, by disdainful English-speaking Quebecers.   At the moment it is threatening to...
results.lead_paragraph: The Commission for the Protection of the French Language, a Quebec provincial agency, is sometimes referred to as the vocabulary constabulary, or the tongue troopers, by disdainful English-speaking Quebecers. At the moment it is threatening to fine the town council here unless it immediately removes two words of English from the facade of the town hall and another three words of English from a sign at the garbage dump. The seven town councilmen, five of whom are French Canadians, voted overwhelmingly early this month to ignore the order to remove the English words and to fight any fine in the courts. Their decision represents the newest serious challenge to Quebec's Charter of the French Language, a measure whose authority was somewhat eroded last week by a court ruling that allowed storekeepers to offer bilingual catalogues rather than the French-only brochures that the provincial government asserted were required by the charter.

headline.main: HELP ON WAY FOR TITLE IX

results.snippet: I knew something was happening in women's sports a few    years back when I went to watch my older daughter play high-school basketball and discovered that the message board in our gym now contained the roster of the girls' varsity. Some...
results.lead_paragraph: I knew something was happening in women's sports a few years back when I went to watch my older daughter play high-school basketball and discovered that the message board in our gym now contained the roster of the girls' varsity. Some administrator had cared enough to send a custodian with a ladder and plastic letters to put the girls' names right next to the scoreboard, formerly reserved for the boys' varsity. Later, I also noticed that one of the school's more experienced male coaches was now coaching my younger daughter on the girls' badminton team. Since then, I have come to appreciate that a lot of the changes in women's sports have been sparked by a piece of legislation known as Title IX.

headline.kicker: REAGAN LEAVES ON TRIP TO CHINA
headline.main: SEEKS TO EASE TENSION IN RELATIONS

results.snippet: President Reagan arrived here today from California on the start of what he called ''a long journey for peace'' to China.   White House officials say the President's six-day visit will include talks on a range of topics aimed at easing tensions...

byline.original: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: President Reagan arrived here today from California on the start of what he called ''a long journey for peace'' to China. White House officials say the President's six-day visit will include talks on a range of topics aimed at easing tensions that have arisen in America's relations with China over the last two years. Officials also say the results of the trip are likely to be a centerpiece of Mr. Reagan's re-election bid. For the first time, Mr. Reagan will be visiting a country that is not a staunch ally; China will be the second Communist country he has ever visited, after East Germany, where he journeyed in 1978. Wide Range of Issues Much of the news coverage is likely to focus on Mr. Reagan's visits to the sites of Peking, Shanghai and the ancient burial pits of Xian. But Administration officials say the chief significance of the President's trip will lie in how much understanding is achieved in discussions with the Chinese leaders on such issues as relations with the Soviet Union and Taiwan, trade, American investment in China and other matters.

headline.main: Three in 'Space' Cast

results.snippet: James Garner will play a senator, Beau Bridges an astronaut and Bruce Dern a scientist who delivers Hitler's leading rocketry experts into American hands in the CBS mini-series ''Space.'' The 13-hour series is based on James A. Michener's...
results.lead_paragraph: James Garner will play a senator, Beau Bridges an astronaut and Bruce Dern a scientist who delivers Hitler's leading rocketry experts into American hands in the CBS mini-series ''Space.'' The 13-hour series is based on James A. Michener's best-selling fictional account of the United States' space program.

headline.main: CANDIDATES BATTLE IN TEXAS PRECINCTS

results.snippet: Gary Hart and Walter F. Mondale have mounted sharp attacks on each other and on the Reagan Administration in their campaigns leading to the Texas Democratic caucuses May 5, but the real battle is being waged with quiet fervor in the precincts.   ...
results.lead_paragraph: Gary Hart and Walter F. Mondale have mounted sharp attacks on each other and on the Reagan Administration in their campaigns leading to the Texas Democratic caucuses May 5, but the real battle is being waged with quiet fervor in the precincts. There are 6,634 precincts across this vast and varied state - ''politically Balkanized'' as one Hart worker put it - and to win any of the 200 national convention delegates ultimately at stake here, the Presidential candidates and their organizations must turn out supporters not once but twice. By the rules of the state's decades- old system, voters must get their names on the voter rolls by voting in the Democratic primary to nominate candidates for offices from county sheriff to the United States Senate. Then, 15 minutes after the polls close at 7 P.M., they must come back to the same precinct to take part in the Presidential caucus.
